customer_name: Kennedy Meadows Wild Canine Conservation Inc.
site_name: Kennedy Meadows Wild Canine Conservation Inc

citations.narrative:
Several outdoor enclosures containing adult wolves had exposed sections of 4inch by 4inch hog wire with sharp points
inside the enclosure. The facility had placed sections of hog wire over large holes that had been dug by wolves, which
created areas in which the animals could become injured or entrapped. There were also portions of wood fencing, plastic
feed and/or water bowls, and plastic enclosures that had been chewed by the animals leaving sharp points. Outdoor
housing facilities must be structurally sound and must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury.
Correct by: 2nd relicense inspection

In several areas of the perimeter fence, there were gaps, trees, or objects that render the fence ineffective. An
approximately 6 inch gap was noted on both sides of a gate in the perimeter fence that could allow potential ingress of
unwanted animals. In two corners of the perimeter fence, the chain link was not firmly attached to the posts allowing the
fencing to be pushed outward leaving approximately 18 inches of fencing unattached at the base. There were several
sections of fencing the were sagging inward and in need of support posts. There were several trees adjacent to the
outside of perimeter fence that were overgrown and/or overhanging, decreasing the effective height. On the inside of the
perimeter fence, there were transport crates and other materials piled against the fence. On the outside of the perimeter
fence there was a pile of pallets stacked adjacent to the fence as well as a shed approximately 10ft x 10ft that also reduce
the effective height of the fence and or provide an access point to go over the fence. In addition, there was an
approximately 20 ft long section of perimeter fence that was also being used as containment for an enclosure housing pet
animals. The fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and
unauthorized persons from going through or under it and having contact with the animals of the facility and so that it can
function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility.
Correct prior to 2nd relicense inspection
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by 11/21/2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
William Campbell, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Several outdoor enclosures containing adult wolves had exposed sections of 4inch by 4inch hog wire with sharp points 
inside the enclosure. The facility had placed sections of hog wire over large holes that had been dug by wolves, which 
created areas in which the animals could become injured or entrapped. There were also portions of wood fencing, plastic 
feed and/or water bowls, and plastic enclosures that had been chewed by the animals leaving sharp points. Outdoor 
housing facilities must be structurally sound and must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. 
Correct by: 2nd relicense inspection 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
In several areas of the perimeter fence, there were gaps, trees, or objects that render the fence ineffective. An 
approximately 6 inch gap was noted on both sides of a gate in the perimeter fence that could allow potential ingress of 
unwanted animals. In two corners of the perimeter fence, the chain link was not firmly attached to the posts allowing the 
fencing to be pushed outward leaving approximately 18 inches of fencing unattached at the base. There were several 
sections of fencing the were sagging inward and in need of support posts. There were several trees adjacent to the 
outside of perimeter fence that were overgrown and/or overhanging, decreasing the effective height. On the inside of the 
perimeter fence, there were transport crates and other materials piled against the fence. On the outside of the perimeter 
fence there was a pile of pallets stacked adjacent to the fence as well as a shed approximately 10ft x 10ft that also reduce 
the effective height of the fence and or provide an access point to go over the fence. In addition, there was an 
approximately 20 ft long section of perimeter fence that was also being used as containment for an enclosure housing pet 
animals. The fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and 
unauthorized persons from going through or under it and having contact with the animals of the facility and so that it can 
function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. 
Correct prior to 2nd relicense inspection 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant.

All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by 11/21/2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
William Campbell, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
